rdf:Description.dc:title: Fresh Water
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Kingsolver, Barbara
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The amount of moisture on Earth has not changed. The water the dinosaurs drank millions of years ago is the same water that falls as rain today. But will there be enough for a more crowded world?
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Environment

rdf:Description.dc:title: The Big Melt
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Larmer, Brook
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Glaciers in the high heart of Asia feed its greatest rivers, lifelines for two billion people. Now the ice and snow are diminishing.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Environment

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sacred Waters
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Newman, Cathy
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: From the droplets in a baptismal font to the scattering of ashes on a holy river, water blesses our lives.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Environment

rdf:Description.dc:title: The Burden of Thirst
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Rosenberg, Tina
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: If the millions of women who haul water long distances had a faucet by their door, whole societies could be transformed.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Environment

rdf:Description.dc:title: Silent Streams
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Chadwick, Douglas
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Freshwater animals are vanishing faster than those on land or at sea. But captive-breeding programs hold out hope.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Environment

rdf:Description.dc:title: Exodus
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Savodnik, Peter
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Less traffic through the Suez Canal means less of everything else for Egyptians; including hope.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geography

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wild Ride
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Stevens, Hampton
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The short and brutal life of a Nascar engine
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Engineering

rdf:Description.dc:title: Outback Steakhouse
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Kamenev, Marina
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Australia’s bush meat is tasty, healthy, and enviro-friendly. But can you get people to eat it?
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Food

rdf:Description.dc:title: Dirigible Dreams
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wallace, Lane
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Is one of aviation's most enduring technological hopes about to become a reality?
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Engineering

rdf:Description.dc:title: E-Donnybrook
rdf:Description.dc:creator: McArdle, Megan
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: No matter who wins the battle between the Kindle and the iPad, it marks the return of machines as market-makers.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Consumer technology

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gray Matter: How to Start a Fire With Only Compressed Air
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Gray, Theodore
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: You've probably seen contestants on Survivor trying to make fire by rubbing sticks together or concentrating sunlight with their eyeglasses. But among preindustrial fire-starting methods, it's hard to beat the portable convenience of fire pistons, used in Southeast Asia since prehistoric times.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dc:title: How It Works: The Most Advanced Gas-Powered R/C Car
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Adams, Eric
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Gas-powered remote-control cars provide realistic racing fun. They burn a gasoline-like fuel called nitro (made of methanol, nitromethane and lubricant) with miniature internal combustion engines. Losi's Ten-T gets even more authentic by adding a starter that works like a diesel engine's. Nitro cars are usually hard to start: You have to pick them up, use a hand-held motor to spin the engine, and simultaneously work the remote's throttle. With the Ten-T you just hit "start" on the remote.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Engineering

rdf:Description.dc:title: Timeline: Sun Power Gets Easier with New Lightweight Panels
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Parsons, Sarah
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Solar power sounds great: electricity from sunshine, for free, no carbon footprint. But solar panels often come with hefty price tags or require complex installations. Now lighter materials are making them less expensive and more convenient, whether you carry them with you or snap them onto your roof.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Environment

rdf:Description.dc:title: Does Geothermal Power Cause Earthquakes?
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Svoboda, Elizabeth
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: On December 8, 2006, Markus Häring caused some 30 earthquakes -- the largest registering 3.4 on the Richter scale -- in Basel, Switzerland. Häring is not a supervillain. He's a geologist, and he had nothing but good intentions when he injected high-pressure water into rocks three miles below the surface, attempting to generate electricity through a process called enhanced geothermal. But he produced earthquakes instead, and when seismic analysis confirmed that the quakes were centered near the drilling site, city officials charged him with $9 million worth of damage to buildings.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Environment

rdf:Description.dc:title: What are Virtual PCs, and What Can I Do With Them?
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Pash, Adam
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: You’ve finally got your PC set up to your liking and running smoothly. So when you decide to add software later on, the last thing you want is something potentially unstable that could endanger the system. Although they’re not a replacement for antivirus applications, virtual machines can really come in handy. Essentially, they’re full-fledged operating systems that run as an application inside your actual operating system while remaining safely isolated from it.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: IT

rdf:Description.dc:title: Breeding the Perfect Bull
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Laskas, Jeanne M.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A Texas cattleman used genetic science to breed his masterpiece – a near-perfect Red Angus bull. Then nature took its course
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biology

rdf:Description.dc:title: Photographing Baltimore's Working Class
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Tucker, Abigail
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Baltimore's A. Aubrey Bodine cast a romantic light on the city's dockworkers in painterly photographs
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Society

rdf:Description.dc:title: Dark Energy: The Biggest Mystery in the Universe
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Panek, Richard
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: At the South Pole, astronomers try to unravel a force greater than gravity that will determine the fate of the cosmos
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Astrophysics

rdf:Description.dc:title: A 160-Year-Old Photographic Mystery
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Fiegl, Amanda
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In 1851, Levi Hill claimed he invented color photography. Was he a genius or a fraud?
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Metascience

rdf:Description.dc:title: Saving the Silky Sifaka
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hendry, Erica R.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In Madagascar, an American researcher races to protect one of the world's rarest mammals, a white lemur known as the silky sifaka
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Environment

rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It's already been announced that Microsoft will be supporting HTML5 video in...

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Foresman, Chris
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Sony has announced it will stop producing 3.5" floppy disks by 2011. We were...
rdf:Description.dc:subject: IT

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Timmer, John
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A good scientific law, like the speed limit imposed by light, may solve an...

rdf:Description.dc:title: Better mental performance may only be a nap away
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Johnston, Casey
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Study participants who were able to take naps long enough to dream were able...
